description: Indicates that this visualization has one or more disclosed data sources
Indicates that the data is open and available
Indicates that there is a link to the data source(s)
Indicates that the data is described in a written article (e.g., scientific paper, public report) with a citation.
Indicates the availability of primary data sources prior to processing, such as handwritten documents, images, text.
Indicates that a visualization author trusts the source for their data indicated
Indicates that data in this visualization can be regularly updating
Indicates data is up-to-date
Indicates that the author wants to disclose limitations with their data, e.g., collection, modeling ...
Indicates that the author wants to disclose limitations with their analysis, without wanting to be too precise at this level.
Indicates some parts of the data is missing
Indicates that a computational model has been used to create the entire or parts of the data set, e.g., for means of approximation or prediction
Indicates that the entire or parts of the data are future prediction implying (unqualified) uncertainty
Indicates that a lot of different sources used in a chart (but not as a composite)
Indicates: The data was reported by subjects (e.g., survey responses, self-assessments).
Indicates: The data was inferred or model-generated (e.g., part-of-speech tagging, predicted age).
Indicates that humans gathered or collected the data by hand (e.g. manual tagging, coding, )
Indicates that the data comes from physicial devices (e.g sensors, lab appartus)
Inidicates that the data was obtained via an API (e.g Twitter data for sentiment analysis)
Indicates the period in which a dataset has been collected
Indicates a named person responsible for data collection
Indicates that the data or visualization has been picked up and reused by someone else.
Indicates that this visualization includes data from more than one source, i.e., implying aggregation and merging operations.
Indicates that a visualization contains a single data source only
Indicates that the author handled missing data via imputation, deletion, or other strategies.
Indicated that the author removed/handled outliers in data set
Indicates that continouse data were converted into bins/buckets
Indicates that certain normalization/scaling techniques were applied. E.g. min-max normalization, z-score standardization)
Indicates that text was tokenized. E.g for NLP tasks
Indicates that PoS was applied. (e.g in NLP pipelines)
Indicates that features were extracted (e.g., SIFT for images, word embeddings for text, etc.)
Indicates that Stemming/Lemmatization was applied on text
Indicates that stop words (e.g and, or, in) have been removed during preprocessing
Indicates that data analysis was performed using an acknowledged and available tool.
Indicates part of the entire data set comes from automatic labeleling
Indicates that data points were selected on a purely random or probabilistic method
Indicates that subgroups (strata) pre-identified, and samples drawn proportionally from each subgroup
Indicates that the datapoints were chosen at a regular interval
Indicates that a subgroup/cluster is used as the sampling unit
Provides a reference to better comprehend used scales/units in the chart.
Indicates that this visualization contains units likely unfamilar to the intended audience.
Highlights the correct interpretation of error bars used in a visualization
Indicates that latest time stamp used in a chart is behind the actual time,
Indicates that data was included or excluded based on a specific time range
Indicates that data was included or excluded based on certain conditions or status indicators
Indicates that the dataset is filtered by location-based rules
Indicates that data was included or excluded based on demographic attributes (e.g., age, gender, income, etc.).
Indicates that data has been manually removed for a given reason, e.g., ...
Indicates that viewers can individualize their chart reading experience by applying sorting and filtering techniques
Indicates that data in the visualization has been aggregated, implying some sort of aggregation method.
Indicates that aggregated or combined data may hide or reverse underlying trends
Reminds the reader of a visualization that a correlation in the visualization may not or knowingly is not a cause.
Indicates that this visualization contains a major finding for the analysis or communication
Indicates that the chart uses a shifted reference point rather than "zero". E.g - per capita rates - moving average ..
Indicates that a visualization algorithm may introduce visual patterns that are not really in the data.
Indicates that data in the visualization may contain rounding errors
Warns the reader that a seemingly obvious visual pattern may lead to false conclusions.
Indicates that only X slected elements are shown
Indicates that this chart was created for the General Public
Indicates that this chart was created for domain experts
Indicates that this chart was created for policy makers
Indicates which licensing information applies for this chart
Indicates which licensing information applies for this chart
Indicates which licensing information applies for this dataset
Indicates a named person responsible for chart creation
Indicates that the chart is about a sensitive topic
Highlights specific domain terminology used in the chart, can potentially include explanations (e.g., kp/co2 is the measure of ...)
Indicates that more background reading is available
Indicates that more details will be provided on hover
Indicates that the map is zoomable
Indicates that the visualized data is pre-filtered but can be manually adjusted
Indicates that the chart is not device responsive
Indicates that the used map projection is not area preserving
Indicates that the placement of the points on the map does not reflect on their exact location (e.g., zipcode).
Highlights how uncertainty is visualized (e.g., error bar, confidence band) and reasons how to correctly read it
Reasons why the uncertainty in the dataset is not visualized. E.g., to keep things simple
Justifies why the axis in the chart is truncated
Justifies non-linear scales
TODO: Check if there is a non-deceptive reason
Indicates that very small data points are over exaggerated to not miss them

badgeName: Some elements too small to be shown
description: Indicates that in the chart some data points/marks are too small that they are not shown
Indicates that colorblind friendly colors are used in the chart
Indicates that printing has been optimized
Indicates that bubbles in the visualization encode a data variable (e.g., size, area)
Highlights visualizations that look similar but require different interpretation
TODO: Check if there is a non-deceptive reason
Justifies why the chart uses rainbow colormaps.
